bibl.title: Letter from L.L. Williams, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, September 12, 1922

div1.p: Williams discusses a bulletin that was distributed to educate the public about mosquitoes. He writes about employing a sanitary officer for malaria education.

div1.head: Letter from L.L. Williams, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, September 12, 1922
div1.opener:
ENNION G. WILLIAMS, M. D.
STATE HEALTH COMMISSIONER
ROY K. FLANNAGAN, M. D.
ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
N. M C
Va
RICHARD MESSER,
CHIEF ENGINEER
M. E. BRYOON, M. D.
DIRECTOR CHILD WELFARE
Commonwealth of Virginia
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
RICHMOND
September 12, 1922.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I see from your letter to Miss Harmon that she sent
you the bulletins that I requested her to send. I must admit
that your criticisms of “Friend Anopheles” are well taken. As
to the why and wherefore explaining or offering any reason in
extenuation of the crime of a supposedly sane antimalaria worker,
allowing the passage and printing of a male A. Quad. with a very
bulbous tipped proboscis, there is none. I saw this cartoon (in
fact it was drawn at my request) before the bulletin was written
(I wrote it myself) and ok'd it for the printer. I hope never
to do such again.

However, the result is better than the effort. The
bulletin is very popular. Our exhibit at the Norfolk fair has
been visited by thousands of people and I know that two thousand
have taken this bulletin away with them. Daily search of the fair
grounds has amply demonstrated that although other bulletins on
malaria and many on rural sanitation have been thrown promiscuously
around the grounds, dropped on every section of the fair grounds,
that in seven days of the fair but one of these bulletins was found.
Even if the reason be that this bulletin is retained with the hope
that the “skeeter” might be of interest to the baby at home or to
keep it quiet while going home, at any rate the bulletin was retain-
ed, which to me is an extremely encouraging sign.

Things in general are commencing to break rather well
in Virginia. The town demonstrations (with the single exception
of Ocean View) have gone extremely well in spite of the ferocious
mosquito season now passing. In addition the Malaria Bureau (Dr.
Kane and I) has succeeded in inducing Suffolk and Nansemond County
to join hands with the State in organizing a combined City County
Health Department. This will take care of future upkeep of Suf-
folk's drainage work and will carry on active efforts looking to-
wards county wide malaria control.

The success of this project and the propaganda plus
the advertisement of the work from other towns (mainly Smithfield,
Lawrenceville, and Oceana) leads us to believe that next season
we will probably be successful in inducing at least two counties to
employ a sanitary officer to do rural malaria control house-to-house
education.

This education is going to largely consist of the estab-
lishment and advertising of gambusia hatcheries, personal education
in the proper use of quinine and screening. The heaviest and main
stress will be placed upon screening as I believe it offers the best
hope of good results.

Any criticisms or suggestions that you might make on
this program would be appreciated.

As to the catechism, I agree most heartily with your
objection to the removal of the illustrations. We have none of the
catechisms left for distribution. We need at least 15,000 for use
in the schools this session. The state appropriation limits the
size of this bulletin so much that it is a case of either omit all
illustrations or else so cut the lesson material as to make it of
very little use for a teaching medium. In a subsequent season we
shall make every effort to secure adequate appropriation to print
a sufficient number of the unabridged catechism, but for this coming
season we must cut our coat according to the cloth.

Gertrude joins me in affectionate regards to you and
Laura.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, L. L. Williams, Jr.,
P. A. Surgeon. LLW:H
